title-group.article-title: Bilious Vomiting Does Not Rule Out Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

article-meta.aff: 1Loma Linda University, Loma Linda, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Andrea W. Thorp, MD, Department of Emergency Medicine, Loma Linda University Medical Center, 11234 Anderson Street, MC-A108, Loma Linda, CA 92354, USA Email: athorp@llu.edu

abstract.p: Objective. To describe the incidence of bilious vomiting in infants with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis that presented to a pediatric emergency department. Methods. A retrospective medical record review included all infants who presented to our level 1 pediatric emergency department from January 1, 2005, through December 31, 2009, who were diagnosed intraoperatively with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Emesis was determined to be bilious if the vomit was described as “green,” “containing bile,” or “bilious.” Results. The authors identified 354 infants with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The median age was 4 weeks 6 days (range = 11 days to 13 weeks). Bilious emesis was encountered in 1.4% (5/354; 95% confidence interval = 0.5% to 3.2%). The pyloric thickness measurements on ultrasound were significantly smaller in those with bilious emesis compared with those without bilious emesis (z score = 2.64; P = .014). Conclusion. Bilious emesis was the presenting symptom in a small proportion of infants with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), or hypertrophied pyloric musculature causing a functional gastric outlet obstruction, is a common cause of vomiting in infants with an estimated incidence of 1 to 8 per 1000 live births per year.1-8 There are features of IHPS that have been consistently reported among various authors at different points, including IHPS consistently affecting male infants 4 to 5 times as often as females, affecting Caucasian infants, and affecting first-born infants of term gestation.1-16 There are, however, some features of IHPS that seem to be changing over time. The previously described “classical” features of IHPS such as hypochloremia, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, palpable pyloric mass, and emaciation are now reported less frequently.6-8,17,18 The description of the vomit seen in IHPS is commonly described as never containing bile, and when bilious vomiting is present, IHPS can be excluded from the differential diagnosis of the vomiting infant.7,10,11,16,17,19-24 There are a few reports of hematemesis being associated with IHPS, but the frequency of hematemesis is low.3,10,20 Although bilious emesis has been described in the context of concomitant gastrointestinal malrotation,25 there is only 1 case report of bilious emesis being described in IHPS without additional gastrointestinal pathology.26

Our clinical experience suggested that IHPS occasionally presents with bilious or bloody vomiting. Our objective is to describe the incidence of bilious vomiting and hematemesis in infants who presented to the pediatric emergency department with IHPS.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We performed a retrospective medical record review and included all infants who presented to our level 1 pediatric emergency department from January 1, 2005, through December 31, 2009. Infants were identified using International Classification of Diseases, Version 9, Clinical Modification codes: 750.5 (congenital HPS), 537.0 (acquired HPS), 787.0 (nausea and vomiting), 578.0 (hematemesis), 779.30-779.34 (newborn vomiting), 536.2 (persistent vomiting), 307.54 (psychogenic vomiting), and 564.3 (bilious vomiting, following gastrointestinal surgery). To our knowledge, there is no standard ultrasound-guided pyloric measurement that is diagnostic of IHPS or a universally accepted definition of IHPS.22-24,27 Therefore, we included only those infants whose diagnosis of IHPS was confirmed by the supervising pediatric surgeon intraoperatively. Infants were excluded if they were older than 16 weeks of age at the time of presentation, were not evaluated in the pediatric emergency department, were directly admitted from another hospital to the surgical team, or those diagnosed with additional gastrointestinal pathology in addition to IHPS.

Data were extracted from the medical record by a single investigator onto a standardized data collection form that included demographic characteristics, duration and description of emesis, examination findings, initial laboratory values, imaging results, and operative confirmation of IHPS. The index visit to the pediatric emergency department was defined as the visit that led to surgery and, therefore, confirmation of IHPS. Emesis was determined to be bilious if the vomit was described as “green,” “containing bile,” or “bilious.” Vomit described as “yellow” was considered nonbilious. Hematemesis was determined if the vomit was described as “coffee-ground,” “blood streaked,” “containing gross blood,” or heme-positive on testing. Emesis was categorized as projectile if described as “projectile” or “forceful.”

Statistical analyses were performed using Stata 9.1 (Stata Corporation, College Station, TX). Mann–Whitney rank sum was used to compare differences in the medians, and confidence intervals were used to describe the proportions. Our institutional review board approved this study.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We identified 646 infants who presented with vomiting to our pediatric emergency department for a total of 659 visits during the 5-year study period. Of those, 305 infants were excluded from analysis and the remaining 354 infants comprised the main study group (Figure 1). The median age of those infants with IHPS was 4 weeks 6 days (range = 11 days to 13 weeks) with 88% being male (311/354). Full-term infants (defined as greater than or equal to 37 weeks gestation) comprised 88% (322/354) of the study group.

When describing the characteristics of the vomiting encountered in infants with IHPS, the median duration of vomiting at presentation to the emergency department was 6.5 days (range = 1 day to 8 weeks) and projectile vomiting was described in 84% of the infants (297/ 354; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 80% to 88%). Hematemesis was encountered in 5% (17/354; 95% CI = 3% to 8%), and 1.4% (5/354; 95% CI = (0.5% to 3.2%) presented with bilious emesis (Tables 1 and 2). Of those that presented with hematemesis, 18% (3/17) had a history of prematurity and none of the infants with bilious vomiting had a history of prematurity. There were no infants that presenting with both hematemesis and bilious vomiting. To compare the characteristics of those infants that presented with bilious emesis to those that did not have bilious emesis, we compared age at the time of presentation, duration of symptoms, and pyloric measurements. The infants presenting with bilious emesis had significantly smaller pyloric thickness measurements on ultrasound compared with those that had no bilious vomiting (z score = 2.64; P = .014). Age at presentation, duration of vomiting, and pyloric length measurements were similar between these 2 groups (Table 3).

sec.p: With regard to the physical examination findings in those infants with IHPS, 39% (139/354; 95% CI = 34% to 45%) had a palpable pyloric mass described by either the emergency medicine physician or pediatric surgeon. Clinical dehydration was described in 17% (61/354; 95% CI = 13% to 22%) of infants, and 8% (29/354; 95% CI = 6% to 12%) were described as “thin,” “malnourished,” or “catechetic.”

All infants in the study group had a serum metabolic panel drawn as part of the emergency department management. Hypochloremia, defined as <98 mmol/L, was present in 30% (107/354; 95% CI = 25% to 35%), 7% (25/354; 95% CI = 5% to 10%) with hypokalemia (<3.5 mmol/L), and 8% (29/354; 95% CI = 6% to 12%) presented with metabolic alkalosis (serum bicarbonate level >33 mmol/L). A total of 97% (343/354) of the infants underwent an abdominal ultrasound to measure the pylorus prior to confirming IHPS intraoperatively. The median length measurement of the pylorus was 19.5 mm (range = 11-28.6 mm), and the median pyloric muscle thickness was 4.3 mm (range = 1.6-8 mm).

In a separate analysis, we encountered 3 infants diagnosed with other gastrointestinal pathology in addition to pyloric stenosis. All 3 of these infants were diagnosed with malrotation of the midgut; 1 presented with bilious vomiting and 1 with hematemesis.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Bilious emesis was present in 1.4% of infants and hematemesis present in 5% of infants diagnosed with IHPS. Even though the proportion of infants with IHPS that present with hematemesis or bilious vomiting is small, the presence of either blood or bile in the vomit did not exclude IHPS as an etiology for infantile vomiting in our study.

The incidence of hematemesis in IHPS has been previously reported in cases series to be 3.4% to 17.5% and is described as being coffee grounds, red or brown streaks, or gross blood.3,10,20 The presence of blood in these infants has been attributed to gastritis due to gastric stasis,3,11 rupture of the mucosal vessels from the force of the vomiting,11 or esophagitis due to esophageal exposure to acidic gastric fluid.20,25

In contrast, bilious emesis in infants with HPS has not been widely described. After an extensive literature search, we found multiple authors describing the vomit of IHPS as nonbilious,7,10,11,16,17,19-24 but found only 1 case report, written in Hebrew, that suggests that bilious vomiting can be a presenting symptom.26 Physiologically, bilious vomiting should not occur in a hypertrophied pylorus that prevents backflow of bile into the stomach. In our study population, bilious vomiting was described in infants with smaller thickness measurements of the pylorus. Therefore, we speculate that bilious vomiting is possible in IHPS through a thickened, but not fully obstructed, pyloric channel into the stomach. Interestingly, those without bilious vomiting had not been vomiting longer at the time of presentation compared with those with bilious vomiting making length of symptoms an unreliable association. Even though earlier detection may have lowered the incidence of electrolyte abnormalities and dehydration as presenting symptoms for IHPS,6-8,17,18 it does not seem to affect the presence of bilious vomiting in our study.

Another commonly described feature in IHPS is the palpable pyloric mass or “palpable olive.” It has been described as the pathognomonic physical exam finding,10 and it has been suggested that the diagnosis of IHPS can be made clinically when the pyloric mass is palpated.21 In our study, the pyloric mass was palpated by either an emergency medicine physician or pediatric surgeon 36% of the time. This is consistent with the downward trend of reported incidence from 79% to 100% prior to 1980 to 23% to 65% in newer series.8,17,21,28,29 The reason for this change is likely due to IHPS being diagnosed earlier in the disease course because of the use of imaging modalities such as ultrasound.6,17,29 Furthermore, other clinical findings that lead to the diagnosis of IHPS, such as dehydration, metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hypochloremia, are decreasing in incidence at the time of diagnosis.6-8,17,18 This is similar to our findings that clinical features consistent with dehydration, malnourishment, or catechetic appearance were reported infrequently.

The main limitation of this study is the retrospective methodology. It is possible that the treating clinician failed to mention all the salient features of the vomiting in the medical record. This would affect the proportions reported in our study. Nonetheless, this suggests that the proportion of infants with bilious vomiting may be higher than we reported.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Bilious emesis and hematemesis were present in a small proportion of infants that presented to the pediatric emergency department with IHPS. Bilious emesis does not rule out infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
